docs.abstract: Apple showed new smartphones — including its biggest ever — for higher prices, and upgraded its smart watches so they become more of a health device.
docs.snippet: Apple showed new smartphones — including its biggest ever — for higher prices, and upgraded its smart watches so they become more of a health device.
docs.lead_paragraph: Apple has long had a playbook for iPhones, its most important product: Keep rolling out bigger, faster and more expensive models.

headline.main: Apple Unveils Bigger iPhones at Higher Prices, and a Heart-Tracking Watch
headline.print_headline: Apple Unveils Bigger iPhones at Heftier Prices

byline.original: By Brian X. Chen, Jack Nicas, Farhad Manjoo and Reed Abelson

docs.abstract: He created the mobile computing companies Palm and Handspring. But for decades his passion has been studying how the human brain works.
docs.snippet: He created the mobile computing companies Palm and Handspring. But for decades his passion has been studying how the human brain works.
docs.lead_paragraph: REDWOOD CITY, Calif. — In the global race to build artificial intelligence, it was a missed opportunity.

headline.main: Jeff Hawkins Is Finally Ready to Explain His Brain Research
headline.print_headline: A New View of How We Think

docs.abstract: In a rural Texas county, lidar sensor technology is being tested as a way to spot illegal intruders from Mexico. That use could divide workers in Silicon Valley.
docs.snippet: In a rural Texas county, lidar sensor technology is being tested as a way to spot illegal intruders from Mexico. That use could divide workers in Silicon Valley.
docs.lead_paragraph: DEL RIO, Tex. — In this tiny town at the edge of South Texas brush country, a black steel fence runs along the Mexican border. About 15 feet high and topped by small metal spires that bend toward Mexico, it stretches west from a Border Patrol checkpoint for about a mile and a half. Then it stops.

headline.main: Parts of a ‘Virtual’ Border Wall, Built With the Tech Behind Driverless Cars
headline.print_headline: It’s the Eyes for a Driverless Car.  What About for a Virtual Border Wall?

docs.abstract: A new flying ambulance service will use small helicopters outfitted with tech that could eventually let them fly without pilots.
docs.snippet: A new flying ambulance service will use small helicopters outfitted with tech that could eventually let them fly without pilots.
docs.lead_paragraph: TRACY, Calif. — Last week, at a tiny airport in the dusty flatlands east of San Francisco, a red-and-white helicopter lifted gently into the air, hovering a few feet over the tarmac. It looked like any other helicopter, except for the small black cube attached to its nose.

headline.main: Silicon Valley Takes a (Careful) Step Toward Autonomous Flying
headline.print_headline: This Time, It’s Unmanned Flight That’s the Next Frontier

docs.abstract: Facing an employee rebellion over work with the Pentagon, the internet giant said its “principles” for A.I. technology would also limit some surveillance work.
docs.snippet: Facing an employee rebellion over work with the Pentagon, the internet giant said its “principles” for A.I. technology would also limit some surveillance work.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google, reeling from an employee protest over the use of artificial intelligence for military purposes, said Thursday that it would not use A.I. for weapons or for surveillance that violates human rights. But it will continue to work with governments and the military.

headline.main: Google Promises Its A.I. Will Not Be Used for Weapons
headline.print_headline: Google Vows Its A.I. Will Not Be Used for Weapons

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

byline.original: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Cade Metz

docs.abstract: Tech employees concerned their products are being deployed for government surveillance or censorship are increasingly asking their employers how the technology is being used.
docs.snippet: Tech employees concerned their products are being deployed for government surveillance or censorship are increasingly asking their employers how the technology is being used.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Jack Poulson, a Google research scientist, recently became alarmed by reports that the company was developing a search engine for China that would censor content on behalf of the government.

headline.main: Tech Workers Now Want to Know: What Are We Building This For?
headline.print_headline: Tech Workers  Take a Stand Over the Uses Of Their Work

byline.original: By Kate Conger and Cade Metz

docs.abstract: European officials hit the internet giant with the record penalty for abusing its power in the smartphone market, the region’s latest move to rein in the clout of tech companies.
docs.snippet: European officials hit the internet giant with the record penalty for abusing its power in the smartphone market, the region’s latest move to rein in the clout of tech companies.
docs.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European authorities fined Google a record $5.1 billion on Wednesday for abusing its power in the mobile phone market and ordered the company to alter its practices, in one of the most aggressive regulatory actions against American technology giants and one that may force lasting changes to smartphones.

headline.main: E.U. Fines Google $5.1 Billion in Android Antitrust Case
headline.print_headline: E.U. Hits Google With Record Fine In Software Case

byline.original: By Adam Satariano and Jack Nicas

docs.abstract: The lab at Alphabet, Google’s parent company, has graduated two projects — one to build delivery drones and another making internet-beaming balloons — into independent businesses.
docs.snippet: The lab at Alphabet, Google’s parent company, has graduated two projects — one to build delivery drones and another making internet-beaming balloons — into independent businesses.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google’s efforts to build delivery drones and internet-beaming balloons are no longer just science projects.

headline.main: Google’s Parent Births New Businesses: Balloons and Drones
headline.print_headline: Alphabet Making Big Strides Refining Balloons and Drones

docs.abstract: Steve Jobs said Apple was 90 days from bankruptcy in 1997. Now it is the first publicly traded American company to be worth $1 trillion.
docs.snippet: Steve Jobs said Apple was 90 days from bankruptcy in 1997. Now it is the first publicly traded American company to be worth $1 trillion.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In 1997, Apple was on the ropes. The Silicon Valley pioneer was being decimated by Microsoft and its many partners in the personal-computer market. It had just cut a third of its work force, and it was about 90 days from going broke, Apple’s late co-founder, Steve Jobs, later said.

headline.main: Apple Is Worth $1,000,000,000,000. Two Decades Ago, It Was Almost Bankrupt.
headline.print_headline: Apple Is Worth $1 Trillion; 21 Years Ago It Was on the Brink of Bankruptcy

docs.abstract: Officially, the move was to tamp down inflation. But policymakers also want to increase the tools at their disposal should the economy suffer after Brexit.
docs.snippet: Officially, the move was to tamp down inflation. But policymakers also want to increase the tools at their disposal should the economy suffer after Brexit.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Bank of England raised interest rates on Thursday to their highest levels in nearly a decade as it seeks to tamp down inflation and make preparations for a potential economic downturn as Britain exits the European Union.

headline.main: Bank of England Raises Interest Rates Amid Brexit Worries
headline.print_headline: Fretting Over Brexit, Bank of England Raises Interest
